comments.commentBody: Second comment!!! Here you go Ms. Katherine :)

That's one of the 3 arrows of Abenomics.  By massive QE. (Printing money) the BOJ pushed down the value of the yen.  But it did nothing for ordinary Japanese whose salaried did not increase but, in real yen , went down because of QE induced inflation.

Because the fact that their worst fears, their most dire predictions, have not come true just makes them angrier and more suspicious. Up here in nice old Illinois a neighbor I love dearly told me back in 2008 that Obama was 'a puppet of the devil'  and would cause the demise of the country.  His charisma, his confidence, were clearly the sign of the devil at work.  It thrilled her to make dark and forboding predictions, they were exciting, it made her feel she had the ability to see things others could not.   This is true of all conspiracy theorists.  It excites them to play out awful scenarios in their mind.

Agreed.
We owe them a debt that can now never be repaid -- but for that very reason, must be the more strongly acknowledged.

Sorry for all the shipmates that were lost and for their families. Their sacrifice are the foundation from which all of us speak freely. I am grateful to them and their families for their sacrifice to this freedom loving nation. They are the best.

As Winston Churchill famously observed:

"If I ask two economists a question I get two answers, unless one of them is Lord Keynes, in which case I get three.”
Makes sense to me.  It will also to you when the drones come THIS way instead of going THAT way.......

So blame the NRA?

If you believe it is a front for the gun makers, then so much of your tax dollars is behind it. The three levels of gov buy LOTS of guns and ammo. And not lever rifles and cowboy revolvers.

And then all the emplyees of the 'agencies' have to buy an 'off duty' gun to go to the supermarket for THEIR protection. Even guys who stamp passports for a living.

But The Dukes of Hazard is yanked from TV because of a flag and that makes America a better place.

Yes, Mr. Carter did a good job. As Mr. Obama is doing now. Thanks to the Internet, the lies spread by con men trying to destroy us don't work any more. Neither does the sarcasm of the people who support the con men. Don't forget that it was the backroom rulers of Reagan who dumped thousands of mentally ill people on our streets by closing state psychiatric hospitals with no care at all for patients, who fired air traffic controllers for striking when they had every right to do so, who caused Iran-Contra, and who proclaimed the fairy tale of "trickle down' economics, which continues to destroy the middle class who are the true builders of this nation. The lies of the 1980s will not stand - we will not let them stand. The time of the con men is over. Rejoice!

This isn't about guns - given the victims were unarmed the assailant could have used a hatchet as effectively. In much of Africa over the last three decades machetes have been the weapon of choice.
Islamist terrorists aren't born, they are evolved from moderate muslims. When will the world demand an end to or at least a reform of Islam. The religion of peace is part of every significant conflict in the world. Will we just sit back and watch the slaughter until we're caught up in it too?
How is it we allow this medieval barbarism to continue and grow unchecked.

I'll be frank, it doesnt sound like your country is very safe. You appear to have non stop shootings there.

You know that in some parts of Africa circumsizing women is considered okay because its "part of the culture". For any sane people guns are in the same category.

Incidentally, I am from a rural area in my country and grew up with guns, shot at my local rifle club for years, and went on to serve as an infantry soldier. I am very familiar with firearms and other weapons. I think I can tell you categorically that there are lots of better ways to bond with kids than playing with firearms.

You have absolutely no idea what you're talking about. I don't even know where the myths about the NRA and the gun industry even began (probably somewhere here in NYT) but they are laughably off-base. Half of the companies that you mentioned not only make guns for the US consumer market but manufacture large contracts for the Army, Navy and Marine Corpse where they go to kill jihadists. They all make guns for lawenforcement as well. Taurus isn't even an American company, they're a Brazilian internationally traded public company.
Gun control is a must. Confronting an extremist version of Islam, too. Neither will happen when the obscurantists come out of the woodwork to confuse the people. But I know.

A lot of truth in your comment -  inequality is a massively problematic issue/fact - but you seem to be suggesting that those (many) Islamist extremists who are willing to kill those who disagree with their Islamist-inspired vision are inspired primarily by some kind of economic motivation rather than by a complex interplay of forces informed primarily by an extremist, religious-inspired worldview in which God is seen as requiring and/or rewarding killing of people based on their religious viewpoints. If that is what you are saying, I strongly disagree. That's all.

For those claiming that if guns were illegal it would force him to use less effective, or more risky means that also is a weak argument.

The fact that something is illegal does not make it impossible to acquire—only a bit more difficult.

Drugs are illegal today, you can go to prison if you make a sale or even for possession. Does that stop hundreds of thousands of people who are motivated from finding ways to get it? Did the prohibition stop people from finding ways to get alcohol? It would not stop someone who is motivated. He would find a way to get the gun, Certainly not someone who is about to engage in terrorism and likely kill himself or go to prison for life.

Making guns illegal would not defend against a motivated terrorist. It would not defend against a motivated, or career criminal. It would not defend against someone who lives in a neighborhood where illegal items are easy to come by (the same neighborhood where most violent gun crime happens.)

It would, however, defend against one specific scenario; someone who is committing a spontaneous act of violence, who lives somewhere where it is relatively hard to get illegal items. That , much narrower, theoretical must now be balanced against the "right to bear arms," the protection of a possibly armed home against burglary, and possibly could be a defense in a violent situation. In Israel a large percentage of "lone wolf terror" is stopped by armed off-duty military—exactly what should have happened here.

Yes, that is actual liberty, it carries risk. Anything less is "everywhere else". The real scary question is why are there persons who are prohibited from owning firearms walking free? If someone is deemed so dangerous that if they acquire a gun they may shoot someone, should that person be in the public?

Sadly, that is how the NRA continues its reign of terror, with the lie that "this is not the time."  This is EXACTLY the time. Putting it off for another day just opens the door to another massacre of innocents by the mentally ill, the evil and the lost. Get real - and cut out the lobbyists talking points - it is NOT the time for NRA marketing slogans. It is the time for action to get guns off the streets of this country.

Whatever the truth behind your criticism of the weapons industry etc., to equate the motivations of each "side" is to ignore the unique threat that extremist Islamic thought and its adherents pose to the world. For all the bad decisions that the US makes, it does not go to war against people or kill them based on an extremist religious worldview in which all people who don't adhere to that religious worldview are seen as fair game for immediate massacre. It's intellectually dishonest to play that game, as fashionable as it seems to be among otherwise intelligent Americans these days. This coming from a liberal Democrat...

Are you suggesting that we should be permanently occupying Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Libya, Lebanon, Somalia, Kuwait, Yemen and every other country where our military has had a physical presence or bled their blood?
what about arming the marines so that they could return fire?

Ahem, Westsider:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hezbollah#Alleged_suicide_and_terror_attacks

Your problem isn't those of us who want gun ownership to be well-regulated as called for by the Constitution, nor is it militant lslam.

Your problem is that increasing numbers of Americans are proving themselves to be irresponsible gun owners. They are the data working against those who refuse to accept the reality that the Second must be managed in a realistic context.

That said, a dose of humility to snuff out the immature snark would go a long way in your effort to be taken seriously.

Congratulations, you fell right into ISIS's trap.  Terrorist groups like ISIS want to defeat strong democracies like the U.S., but of course they are too weak to invade or defeat us. They must make us defeat ourselves, by scaring us and making us angry enough to devote more and more of our wealth to fighting them and securing our government/military facilities.  Look at our response to 9/11: how much did our response cost (and continue to cost in caring for the wounded) and what did we accomplish?  Do you really want us to continue spending billions of dollars and thousands of lives for a fight we almost certainly can't win?

Could it be because it's not Guatemalans who have a long history of attacking Americans but, rather, extremist Islamists? Comments like your express a sentiment so barren of perceptive insight and reality that it is hard not to wonder whether you are someone who thinks, like this shooter did, that the whole world should have to live under Sharia law.

Well, to be honest, I've seen images of BGM 71 Anti tank missiles (made by Raytheon) in the hands of "moderate" syrian rebels which then were "acquired " by IS. It's not a secret, they have US supplied equipment delivered by the current administration. If the US ever goes into Syria we will certainly have to face that music.

If I recall, the second amendment associates the right to own guns with the context of a well regulated militia.  If gun control laws were required to reflect properly the second amendment to the Constitution, we would all be better off.
Ah, another apologist for extremist religious fanatics who are, as another reader put it, at war with civilization in general. Nice to see so many of you all today.
